Do you want to explain some of the activities that you think you have been involved with
or others that you see being held
that have been quite useful to people with learning disabilities in the county?
There's numerous, well, it's very well documented
in terms of the lunches, the Christmas lunches and the parties
and the gateway clubs that go on
that is very needed for people in rural areas
particularly where there's not a lot of social activities going on.
So that's one aspect of it.
The other side of Mencap Ceredigion in terms of the gardening projects,
I'm a trained horticulturalist and a qualified gardener with insurance
able to provide some of those projects recently
in terms of tree planting and the camaraderie that's come about in those groups, Maysian.
And you also recently took part in the stall projects that we have, the market stalls?
Yeah, the market stalls and also the lead up to the animated
anime festival raising money for Mencap Ceredigion
and also promotion of Mencap Ceredigion services both in the local and local areas.
Promotion of Mencap Ceredigion services both in Aberysworth, Aberyrwyrn and Newquay
to make people aware of what's going on there, getting business support
to be able to put up leaflets in their shops and businesses.
How important do you think, I mean a lot of that is within the community,
how important has that been for our members do you feel?
How important is that?
Very important in so many different levels in terms of skillsharing and knowledge
and the ability to provide those, to make people aware
but also to give people that are providing those stalls that have learning disabilities
a feeling of involvement in a real sense rather than in a participatory sense
because the people that are being involved in the stalls have also gone on to talk in events
and to promote awareness around learning disabilities
and there's nothing better advocate than somebody that lives that life.
You've also been involved in volunteering for us and so forth
but you've also been involved in working for a volunteering organisation.
Can you explain a little bit about that and how that's helped people with,
how important volunteering is then for people in general?
I was a development officer for a local voluntary organisation
that helps people get involved and supports voluntary organisations within Celyddigion.
What I was able to do was again to be empathetic in terms of an understanding of what people's needs,
both from the organisation and the individual's point,
but also to give people confidence to be able to take that little step forward,
to apply for things that they were interested in rather than somebody saying,
you've got to go and do this today.
So it was that kind of middle fence thing really.
You've been involved now in the field of learning disabilities for what we said over 20 years now really.
How have things changed do you feel?
Well.
And what's changed?
